passage:
It has been clearly documented that crime levels in the United States have been falling for some time. In fact, crime levels today are at their lowest level since the 1960s. Adding positive news to these statistics is that many states are heeding the call for reforms in sentencing and corrections procedures. The goal of these reforms is not only to keep people out of prison but also to enhance the efficacy of the parole system, for example, by helping to provide adequate housing or employment to convicted felons. Even so, over half of inmates released will be arrested again within three years because of their inability to find a stable job and a place to live, their need for medical care, or a lack of practical education and training.
	It is also well known that the jail population of the United States has grown to an alarming size of 2.3 million people in some form of incarceration or detention. Globally, the United States has the highest rate of incarceration at 670 per 100,000 people. Studies have shown that one of the reasons for this dramatic increase is the war on drugs, as a citizen can be arrested for the possession of minute amounts of an illegal substance, and prison sentences for drug offenses are disproportionately long. One in five inmates in federal prison is there for a nonviolent drug offense.
	This increase has had the direst consequences in African American communities, where males are six times more likely to be incarcerated than white males. This statistic is also true of black women, whose incarceration rate is four times that of white females. Hispanic and Latino males are two times more likely to be incarcerated than white males. The loss of a central male figure in the household because of incarceration breaks up families and reduces income, raising the poverty level. Children of incarcerated parents are five times more likely to engage in risky or criminal behavior.
	There is also an aging prison population in this nation because people are serving more time than those in past decades. More than 160,000 people are serving life sentences, with and without the possibility of parole. Another 44,000 are serving virtual life sentences, where the inmate is not expected to survive to be released. Each year of a prison life sentence that begins in a person’s 30s costs an average of $1 million. Seventeen thousand prisoners are serving life sentences for nonviolent crimes.
	It is evident that the current measures to substantially reduce the US jail population are a step in the right direction but are not enough. City and state officials must come together to brainstorm new solutions and put forward more reforms to decrease initial incarceration rates and reduce recidivism, lowering the overall prison population over time.

questions.description: Which of the following statements best supports the main point of the passage?

options.description: Local communities are often hardest hit by this dire situation.
Reducing incarceration rates will reduce poverty levels andimprove the economy.
Most people serving life sentences have the possibility of parole.
There are more people in jail today than there were 20 years ago.

questions.description: As used in line 5, the word efficacy most nearly means

options.description: “degree.”
“competence.”
“calumny.”
“novice.”

questions.description: Based on the second paragraph, the author would most likely agree with which of the following statements:

options.description: The United States has more criminals than any other country.
Drug-related crimes are the most serious and deserve theharshest punishments.
The United States has more nonviolent criminals in jail thanviolent criminals.
Our legal system is more effective at putting criminals in jail.

questions.description: The first paragraph serves mostly to

options.description: exculpate the failures of the US judicial system.
explain the current state of US corrections procedures.
provide evidence for the need for the war on drugs.
warn against the consequences of a felony record.

questions.description: In paragraph 2, the word disproportionately most nearly means

options.description: “equitably.”
“logistically.”
“unreasonably.”
“subtly.”

questions.description: In the third paragraph, the author suggests that

options.description: the increase of incarceration in America is felt most strongly byminorities.
men are much more likely to be sentenced on drug charges.
women are receiving ineffective or incompetent counsel in thefirst stages of the criminal justice system.
Hispanics are the second-largest minority group in US prisons.

questions.description: In paragraph 3, the word direst most nearly means

options.description: “fortuitous.”
“quixotic.”
“abnormal.”
“most severe.”

questions.description: The author mentions the aging prison population in order to

options.description: emphasize the insidious nature of Alzheimer’s disease.
imply that senior citizens are committing more crimes.
provide another reason for the current US jail population crisis.
protest the abolition of the death penalty in most states.

questions.description: In paragraph 4, it could be inferred that the author

options.description: does not believe in giving prisoners parole.
believes that many prisoners who have life sentences do notdeserve them.
believes the money spent on lifelong prisoners might be betterused elsewhere.
does not believe nonviolent offenders should be in jail.

questions.description: Based on the table, which of the following statements is true?

options.description: States with higher incarceration rates have higher poverty levels.
States with lower incarceration rates have fewer prisons.
Murders account for most of the incarcerated population.
Poor states have more crime.

questions.description: Which of the following statements could be inferred from the table?

options.description: Geographical location has a significant impact on murder rates.
Southern states have more prisons because the South lost theCivil War.
Poverty levels are strong indicators of higher crime rates andprison populations.
The higher incarceration rates are due to more life sentences.
